EditInstructions.*:
You can configure what system properties (ID/Guid etc.) will be included in serialized data. This allows you to harden the APIs and not include any data you don't want to. Read about it in the docs.

This doesn't prevent code or data-sources from accessing the properties, but ensures that it won't be included in the JSON when serialized for WebApi.

This should usually be your last step in a Query, as other processing after this may prevent the configuration from reaching the serializer.

Notes.*: Configures how to serialize data coming through this DataSource.
Just a title for you to identify this data.

Notes.en-us: Notes for your own use, to document why you did this.

Notes.*: This is about general system properties like ID, Guid and internal dates etc.

DropdownValues.*:
System Default (include for editors, don't for viewers):
Don't include:false
Include:true

Notes.en-us: Normally not needed, but in rare cases where we load from multiple Apps it helps the UI to not offer edit-buttons.
Include information about the Content Type

DropdownValues.en-us:
:System Default (don't include)
false:Explicitly Don't include
object:Include as an object structure
flat:Include as flat properties

Notes.*: This determines how information about related items / entities are included in the JSON.

DropdownValues.en-us:
:System Default (return an object)
false:Return object
true:Return comma separated list of IDs as a string
array:Return a real array [..., ...] - especially for JSON

Notes.*: In case you're new to Metadata, read the docs.

Notes.en-us: If an entity is metadata for something else, this would include the target information.
If you need to know more, read about metadata.

DropdownValues.en-us:
:System Default (include for editors, don't for viewers)
false:Don't include
true:Include

Notes.en-us: These settings should make the JSON smaller, for example by not transporting null values. This is still experimental.
Will make the JSON smaller by omiting null values (usually null-strings).

DropdownValues.en-us:
:System Default (don't remove)
false:Don't remove null values
true:Remove null values

Notes.en-us: Will make the JSON smaller by omitting zero values (usually numbers).

DropdownValues.en-us:
:System Default (don't remove)
false:Don't remove zero values
true:Remove zero values

Notes.en-us: Will make the JSON smaller by omitting empty strings.

DropdownValues.en-us:
:System Default (don't remove)
false:Don't remove empty strings
true:Remove empty strings

Notes.en-us: Will make the JSON smaller by omitting false booleans.

DropdownValues.en-us:
:System Default (don't drop/remove)
false:Don't drop/remove false booleans
true:Drop / Remove false booleans

Description.*: used to configure an App DataSource

EditInstructions.*: Learn more about the App data source in the wiki.

Notes.en-us: Leave blank by default (to get data from current app). If you give this an App number then the data provided by this source will come from that app. Learn more in help.
These are very experimental settings, you should not use them yet.
This is a super advanced setting, you should normally not use this.

DropdownValues.en-us:
:Not set (default) - without ancestors
true:With ancestors
false:Without ancestors

EditInstructions.*: Modify how attributes are renamed. For more information, check out the AttributeRename docs.

Notes.*: Just a title so you know what this configuration is for.

Notes.en-us:
The renaming map for the attributes. This is multi-line, one rename per line. The syntax:

NewFieldName=OldFieldName
NewField2=OldFieldName2

Notes.*: Advanced settings - we recommend to leave the default settings.

Notes.en-us: If true, the attributes / fields / properties which have not been renamed are preserved. If false, your new Entity only contains the renamed fields.
Leave empty to keep the previous type name. If you add something here, the modified entities will have this new type name.

Description.*: Used to configure an AttributeFilter DataSource

EditInstructions.*: Filter out attributes/properties you don't want to pass on. This is usually to keep the output smaller, or to hide fields which you don't want to be published on the wire. Read about it in the docs.

Notes.*: Just a title to help you identify this data.

Notes.en-us: Notes for your own use, to document why you did this.

Notes.*:
Put one property name on each line.

You can also leave the list empty if to keep all or remove all.

DropdownValues.en-us:
Keep only attributes/properties listed below (default):+
Remove only attributes/properties listed below:-

Notes.en-us: Write the attributes you want to keep in here. All others won't be passed on and won't be available upstream.

Notes.*: Just a nice title so you know what this cache-component should do for you. Learn more about the CacheAllStreams data source.

Notes.en-us: This is to cache things where the up-stream is already cached - for example when caching a filtered list of 2sxc-content-items. When this is set, the cache will check if the up-stream has been reloaded and if it has, then it will rebuild this cache as well. Learn more and check out best practices in help.
How long the cache will be kept / when it will be refreshed automatically. Common numbers are 86400 (1 day) or 3600 (1 hour). Learn more in help.

EditInstructions.en-us:
The Children Data Source will get you the children relationships of all the items in the Default In-Stream. Note that if you need parent relationships, use the Parents DataSource.

You only need the Default In-Stream, because the items themselves already know about their relationships. The resulting stream will contain all the children matching the criteria provided.

DropdownValues.en-us:
true:True - filter duplicates, return each entity once even if referenced many times
false:False - don't filter, return each related entity even if it's referenced many times

Notes.en-us: The field which contains the related items/entities. If you leave this empty, it will get you all the childen of the incoming items, on every relationship field.

Placeholder.en-us: Type field name if you only want the relationships of a specific field

TitleTrue.en-us: Also filter by Type of the Related Item

Notes.en-us:
Setting the ContentType is rarely needed, which is why the settings is hidden by default. 

Make sure you really need to set this - otherwise best leave as is.

Description.en-us: Module DataSource with Data of a specific module

EditInstructions.en-us: This will return the items of a Module Instance, in two streams Content and Header. By default, it takes the module-id from the current context, but you can specify a specific module if you need it. Read more in the docs about the CmsBlock DataSource.

Notes.*: just a title for your own use - not important

Notes.en-us: general notes so you know what this is for - like "this is the module where the editor configures xyz-settings"
The moduleID or a token giving you the module. By default it's [Module:Id]

EditInstructions.*: This DataSource will read CSV files and provide them as Data Entities. Best read the docs.

Notes.*: Just a title to help you know what this is for.

Notes.en-us: Notes to help you remember why you configured stuff :)
File path relative to the web root, for example '/Portals/0/Data/MyMeasurements.csv' or '[App:Path]/demo.csv'. Read the online help for more.
Delimiter of values in the rows, for example the ';', ',' or tab. Leave blank for default (i.e. the tab). Read the online help for more incl. how to add special characters like tab.
The content type of the entities passed to the output stream. This can be an arbitrary name.
The case sensitive name of the column that should be used for the entity IDs. If no name is specified, the row numbers will be used for the IDs. See the online help for more.
The case sensitive name of the column used for the entity titles. Leave blank to automatically take the first column.

Description.*: used to configure an EntityIdFilter DataSource

EditInstructions.*: Use the Item-Id Filter to keep only one or a few items - of which you know the ID. The ID can also come from a URL or something, when used in details-pages. Read about it in the docs.

Notes.*: Comma separated list of Entity IDs, like 503,522,5066,32

Description.*: used to configure an EntityTypeFilter DataSource

EditInstructions.*: Learn more about the content-type / Entity-type filter in the wiki.

Notes.*: The name of the content type

Description.*: Change tabular language data into Entities.

EditInstructions.*: This helps you turn tabular language data into multi-language properties the way 2sxc uses it.

Notes.*: Just a title for you to give this configuration a name.

Notes.en-us: just notes for yourself to better understand what this is for

Notes.*: Enter one mapping each line. Example: Target:Source will change the attribute name of 'Source' field to 'Target'. For multi-language mappings, use commas to separate languages and = to separate language and source field. Example: Value:en-us=ValueEn,de-de=ValueDe will map ValueEn and ValueDe to a new field Value which contains both values as multi-language entity.

EditInstructions.en-us: This will retrieve Metadata of the items in the default stream. In most cases you don't really want to configure much here. See Metadata docs.

Notes.en-us: In most cases you will just want to get all the metadata of an item, no matter what type the metadata has. But in very complex situation an item could have a lot of metadata, so you may only want to retrieve specific types you care about.

EditInstructions.en-us:
This will get you the targets of metadata - so if an item is metadata, it will get you the items which this metadata describes. See Metadata Targets docs.

Important: it can only get you Entity targets. So if your metadata describes something else, it will not be included here.

Notes.en-us: Limit the returned items to such that have the specified content type.

TitleFalse.en-us: Don't filter duplicates (return them as often as they are used)

TitleTrue.en-us: Filter duplicates (return them only once - default)

EditInstructions.*: Used to show only items which were created / owned by a specific owner. Read the docs for more.

Notes.*: The identifier of the user - in DNN it could be the sequence 'dnn:userid=[User:UserId]'. Learn more on 2sxc.org/help?tag=datasource-filter-owner

EditInstructions.*: Read the docs.

Notes.*: Any title you want - for your convenience to name this. If you need any help, check out 2sxc.org/help?tag=ds-paging

Amount of items per page. By default this is 10. Also set this to the amount you want if you're using this to just get a short-list of 5 items or something - then set to 5. You could also use parameters like [QueryString:ItemsPerPage] but in general you'll probably want a number or something.

DropdownValues.*:
10
25
50
100
get count from url:[QueryString:Count]
get pagesize from url:[QueryString:PageSize]

Notes.*: The page we're on, by default it's 1. If you only want to use the first page (like get the top 5 of something) then set 1. Otherwise use a url parameter or something - so you would use [QueryString:Page] or similar. Check out 2sxc.org/help?tag=ds-paging for more help.

DropdownValues.*:
1
get page from url:[QueryString:Page]
get p from url:[QueryString:P]
get PageNum from url:[QueryString:PageNum]

EditInstructions.en-us:
Use the Parents DataSource to retrieve items/entities which point to the items/entities in the Default In-Stream. Note that if you need children relationships use the Children DataSource.

You only need the Default In-Stream, because the items themselves already know about their relationships. The resulting stream will contain all the parents matching the criteria provided.

DropdownValues.en-us:
true:True - filter duplicates, return each entity once even if referenced many times
false:False - don't filter, return each related entity even if it's referenced many times

Notes.en-us: Type of the parents to retrieve. If left empty, will retrieve all parents, no matter what type they are.

Field on the parent which points to this item. Use this if parents can have multiple fields (like Author and Illustrator) referencing this item, and you only need one of them. 

If you leave this empty, it will get all the relationships, no matter what fields refer to them.

EditInstructions.*: Request data from another query. See docs.

Notes.*: just a title so you know what it's about
Pick the query you want to run.
List of params - one per line. Format key=value. Can be tokenised like key=[QueryString:Id].

Description.en-us: used to configure a RelationshipFilter DataSource

EditInstructions.en-us:
This will filter the items and only return those with the relationship-requirements as configured. See also Relationship Filter docs.

Important: If you only want to get all the children or parents of an entity, use the Children or Parents DataSource instead.

Notes.*: just a title so you know what it's about

Notes.en-us: your notes about this filter, to help you remember what you were thinking...

Notes.*: Here you can specify what relationship you are comparing for, and what value you expect in the related items. If the list contains Book items and you want to keep only those with the Author being Daniel Mettler, then you would type Author in the relationship-field and Daniel Mettler in the filter-value field.
The property we're comparing. So if this is a list of books, and we want to check which ones have an Author called "Daniel", then the relationship-field is Author

the value we want in the related data - if you're on a book-list and only want those with the Author "Daniel", then this is where you would write Daniel. Remember that you can also use tokens, like [QueryString:Author]
Sometimes you want to use much more advanced comparisons or compare on another field than just the title.

The field of the related items we're checking for. By default it's the title (EntityTitle), but you could also check for the ID (EntityId) or for other properties. For example, if you have a list of books and you only want to keep those of Authors who are from Switzerland, then here you would not write EntityTitle, but instead Country.

This determines how we will compare. The following operations exist in 2sxc 9.9+:

  1. the (blank) default is the same as contains - we will check if the related items contains such an item, so if in a list of tags, one has all the mentioned tag(s)
  2. with a not-contains the related items may not contain all of the tags 
  3. if you use containsany, it will return all items where the related-items has any one of the filter criterias
  4. with a not-containsany, it will return those which don't have any of the items you listed in filter
  5. in case of a first the first item in the relationships must be what we want - this is typical for lists where the first item is like the primary category. If you specify multiple items in filter, the first will be valid if it matches any of those.
  6. in case of a not-first the first item may not match this
  7. use any it will ignore the filter-value and simply keep all items having any relationships 
  8. with not-any it will return all items not having any relationships
  9. with count it will keep all items having exactly the desired amount of related-items, the amount is specified in the filter-field
  10. if not-count it will keep all items having a different amount than the desired amount

DropdownValues.*:
(default = contains):
contains - keep these that have all of these:contains
not-contains - keep these that don't have all:not-contains
containsany - keep these that have any of these:containsany
not-containsany - keep these that have none of these:not-containsany
first - keep these where the first item is one of these:first
not-first - keep these where the first item is none of these:not-first
any - keep these that have relationships:any
not-any - keep these that have no relationships:not-any
count - keep these with the exact child-amount in filter:count
not-count - keep these with a different child amount than in filter:not-count

Notes.*: if you want to check for multiple relationships (like having multiple tags), then the filter-value will contain a string with multiple values. By default the separator is blank - so the filter-value will not be separated. Usually you would use a comma, so that you can write "online,2017,seo", but there are cases where your strings may themselves contain commas - so this is why you can specify your own separation character.

EditInstructions.en-us: Configure which roles will be returned by this data source. See docs.

EditInstructions.*: Use this to configure how shuffling should work. Basically just specify how many items should be returned in the end. Learn more about this in the 2sxc docs on the Shuffle DataSource page.

Description.*: Config type for the Sql DataSource

EditInstructions.*:
Use the SQL DataSource to get SQL data. Just write a SELECT ... FROM ... and you're good to go. 

If this is the first time you're using this, you may want some help to get started. You can find more help in the 2sxc docs (see SqlDataSource) or in the general 2sxc help about data sources.

Notes.*: just a nice name so you remember what it's for

Notes.en-us: just add some notes for yourself, so you know what the query is for and what special things you did to make it work

Notes.*: How to connect to the DB

Notes.en-us: Use connection names from web.config / appsettings.json. To enter another Manual Connection Name use the TT button to the right.

Notes.*: alternative: write the connection string instead of the connection name
What do you want to query, and how to treat the result

DefaultValue.en-us:
-- Demo SQL - select top 10 table names

SELECT Top(10) *
FROM SYSOBJECTS
WHERE xtype = 'U'

Notes.en-us: SQL select statement

Notes.*: Name of the content-type in result
name of the ID field, if blank, defaults to EntityId
name of the title field, if blank, defaults to EntityTitle

EditInstructions.*: Pick a stream to be passed on. Usually you will use some kind of parameter, like [Params:Stream]

Notes.*: Name of the stream to be provided.

EditInstructions.*: Get a list of apps - either of the current zone (default / empty) or of a selected zone. For more help, read the docs.

Notes.*: just notes for yourself to better understand what this is for
The number of the zone of which you want to get the apps. If blank, it won't return any apps.

EditInstructions.*: Get the attributes of a content-type. For more help, read the docs.

Notes.*: just notes for yourself to better understand what this is for
Choose the content-type of which you want to see the attributes

EditInstructions.*: Query what content-types you want. If left blank, will use current app. Read more about this in the wiki.

Notes.*: just notes for yourself to better understand what this is for
The ID of an app or a token which delivers it. Will use current app if left empty.
The scope for which to get the content-types - by default it's always Default

EditInstructions.*: Use this to configure a query-info datasource. This is a very advanced topic, read more about it in the docs.

Notes.*: just notes for yourself to better understand what this is for
Select a query...
Select a stream of the query you choose.

EditInstructions.*:
Use this to connect records which are tabular but would represent a hierarchy / tree-structure. Data passing through this data source will then have Children / and or Parent-relationships. 

Note that the purpose of this is really to build a tree structure, so it assumes that each child can only have one parent / folder.

Notes.*: Just a title for you to give this configuration a name.

Notes.en-us: just notes for yourself to better understand what this is for

Notes.*:
We need two things

  1. References on the Children to Parents
  2. Ways to find the Parent / Folder etc.

Name.*: Field pointing to the Parent or Folder ID

Notes.*: The property on the Child with points to the parent. It should contain a GUID or a number.

Name.*: Identifier of the Parent / Folder (Parent ID)

Notes.*:
Enter the attribute which should be used to identify entities. The datasource will look for entities in the 'Children' stream with a 'Child Parent Attribute' that matches the 'Parent Identifier Attribute' in the 'Default' stream.
Currently this datasource only supports EntityGuid and EntityId.
Configure the fields which will contain the relationships.

Name.*: Property of Parent to Access Children

Notes.*: Property where the child relationships are mapped. If you enter Children you can access the child entities with item.Children.

Name.*: Property of Child to Access Parent

Notes.*: Property where the parent relationship is added. If you enter Folder  you can access the parent Entity with item.Folder.

DropdownValues.en-us:
false:Don't include System Admins
true:Include System Admins
required:Include ONLY System Admins

Notes.en-us: Include the Field Roles referencing the roles each user is in.

DropdownValues.en-us:
:Default (add)
false:Do not add Roles
true:Add Roles

Description.*: used to configure a ValueFilter DataSource

EditInstructions.*: Check out the docs.

Notes.*: The object attribute (property) we will filter on, like "FirstName" or similar. Find more help about this filter here.

Notes.en-us: This determines how things will be compared, so if it's a "field = value" or "field contains value" etc. There are many operators and which one you use depends a bit on what data-type you are comparing. For example, a number can be "between 17 and 25" or a text can "!contain daniel". Read more about the possible operators in help.

DropdownValues.en-us:
== equals (case insensitive, numbers, etc.):==
=== case-sensitive, exact equals:===
!= not equal, case insensitive:!=
begins means it begins with this:begins
contains means it contains this:contains
!contains doesn't contain:!contains
> for numbers:>
< for numbers:<
>= for numbers:>=
<= for numbers:<=
between for numbers - in filter use '7 and 10':between
!between for numbers - use '7 and 10:!between
between for dates - use '2016-01-01 and 2017-01-01':between
!between for dates - use '2016-01-01 and 2017-01-01':!between
get Operator from url:[QueryString:Operator]

Notes.*: The information we want to use to filter - like "John" or "[QueryString:Name]". There are many things you can do with this, so always check more information in help.
Get only 1 or whatever amount you need. This improves performance if you have many thousand items, and only need a few. Leave blank to take all.
Choose which language this filter is applied to.

DropdownValues.*:
System Default (only primary language):
Only primary language:default
First try current language (otherwise fall back to primary):current
English US (for other language, switch to type-mode and enter it there):en-US
Use language from url-param language:[QueryString:language]

Description.*: used to configure a ValueSort DataSource

EditInstructions.*: Read more about this in the docs

Notes.*: Names of attributes (fields), sepparated by a comma
if you have multiple fields to sort by, switch to manual entry in the field
Choose which language this sort is applied to.

DropdownValues.*:
System Default (only primary language):
Only primary language:default
First try current language (otherwise fall back to primary):current
English US (for other language, switch to type-mode and enter it there):en-US
Use language from url-param language:[QueryString:language]

Notes.en-us: By default, most special page types are not returned.

Name.en-us: Include Links-Only Items from the Navigation

Notes.en-us: These are virtual pages which actually just point to some URL.
These are pages which are configured to not show in the menu.
These are pages which are deleted and still in the recycle bin.
These are pages to admin the current site, such as file manager.
These are pages to admin the current system, such as modules management.

Name.en-us: Permissions the Current User Must Have
Only Include Pages to Which the User has View Permissions
Only Include Pages to Which the User has Edit Permissions

EditInstructions.en-us: Configure what the SystemStack DataSource should return.

Notes.en-us: Which stack you want.
Determine if you also want the values of settings. If no you'll just get the keys.

DropdownValues.en-us:
:Default - add values
true:Add Values
false:Do not add values

EditInstructions.en-us: Specify how to get lists of files and/or folders from the App.

Notes.en-us: Just a title so you can remember what this does.
The starting folder in the app, where retrieving files should start. Must begin with a "/"
Which files to retrieve.

Value,Title
false,"Do not search subfolders (default)"
